name: Middlesbrough FC History Multiple Choice Quiz | Middlesbrough | 10 Questions

questions.text: In what year were the club formed?
questions.explanation:
1876.

	Members of the Middlesbrough Cricket Club formed the team in 1876 and a year later, they played their first recorded game which ended in a 1-1 draw with Teeside Wanderers.

questions.text: Where did the club first play their home games?
questions.explanation:
Old Archery Ground.

	Middlesbrough played at the Old Archery Ground from 1877-79, followed by Breckon Hill until 1892, when they had a spell at Linthorpe Park until 1903. The club then moved to Ayresome Park, which was their home until moving into the brand new Riverside Stadium in 1994.

questions.text: Who was the club's first manager in their history?
questions.explanation:
John Robson.

	Robson was at the helm between 1899-1905, when Alex Massie took over for a year. Andy Aitken followed until 1909, followed by short spells by J Gunter (1908-10) and A Walker (1910-11), until Tom McIntosh became manager until 1919. John Robson went on to manage Manchester United at the start of World War I, until 1921.

questions.text: Which of these played the most League games for the club?
questions.explanation:
Tim Williamson.

	Williamson played an amazing 563 games for Middlesbrough between 1902-23. Souness amassed 178 League games between 1972-78. Camsell played 453 games from 1925-46, and Mannion played 368 games between 1937-54.

questions.text: From which team did Middlesbrough sign Gareth Southgate in 2001?
questions.explanation:
Aston Villa.

	Southgate was born in Watford in 1970, and signed for Crystal Palace as a trainee in 1989 where he played 152 League games between 1989-95, before signing for Aston Villa. At Villa Park, he played 191 League games until 2001, when Middlesbrough snapped up the England international defender.

questions.text: How many goals did Brian Clough score for Middlesbrough?
questions.explanation:
204.

	Clough's 204 goals came in just 222 games; almost a goal a game! A true legend of the game, Clough made his Middlesbrough debut in 1955, before signing for Sunderland in 1961. Sadly, Clough died at the age of 69 in September, 2004.

questions.text: Which team did Middlesbrough beat 9-0 to set a record for their highest League win?
questions.explanation:
Brighton & Hove Albion.

	Middlesbrough hammered Brighton 9-0 in August 1958 to set the record. Incidentally, they lost 9-0 to Blackburn Rovers which set the record for their heaviest defeat.

questions.text: Middlesbrough were promoted to the Premiership in the 1994-95 season, after winning the Championship title. Which other team were promoted alongside them that season?
questions.explanation:
Bolton Wanderers.

	Middlesbrough finished as champions on 82 points, with Reading 2nd on 79. Bolton ended 3rd, but were promoted via the play-offs. Relegated from the Premiership that season were Crystal Palace, Norwich City, Leicester City and Ipswich Town.

questions.text: In the 2004-05 Premiership season, Middlesbrough earned a UEFA Cup place by drawing with which team on the last day of the season?
questions.explanation:
Manchester City.

	Middlesbrough drew 1-1 with each of these teams, but on the final day of the season, they needed to avoid defeat at the City of Manchester Stadium, and did so via Jimmy-Floyd Hasselbaink's goal in the 23rd minute. Kiki Musampa levelled the score for City, but it was Middlesbrough that gained the UEFA Cup place.

questions.text: What feat did Middlesbrough achieve in the 1996-97 season?
questions.correct: Reached the FA Cup and League Cup finals
options: Beat Manchester United home and away
questions.explanation:
Reached the FA Cup and League Cup finals.

	While Middlesbrough were relegated from the Premiership in the 1996-97 season, they also reached the League Cup final, where Steve Claridge's extra-time goal gave Leicester City a 1-0 victory. A month later, they played in the FA Cup final, where Chelsea took the Cup with goals from Roberto Di Matteo in the 1st minute, and Edide Newton in the 83rd.
